pageTitle: ECE Focus Area: Business (Electrical) | Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering | College of Engineering | The University of Iowa
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {37564=College of Engineering The University of Iowa 4016 Seamans Center for the Engineering Arts and Sciences Iowa City, Iowa, 52242}
textBeforeTable: Students interested in the business elective focus area should identify a second electrical track technical focus area of interest, and consider the course selection suggestions listed both there, and below, when completing their plan of study form. Electrical engineers with business backgrounds find employment in all engineering industries, as project leaders, mid-level managers, and even as CEOs. In fact, a recent SpencerStuart study found that 20% of all Fortune 500 CEOs hold engineering degrees of some kind. Depending on the courses selected electrical track students in the business focus area can earn a business minor without taking any courses beyond those required to complete their B.S.E. degree. In addition to their EE courswork the focus area provides background in engineering economics, financial management, business law, and marketing. Electrical engineering studies provide a great foundation for business decision-making because they couple objective analysis with the development of strong problem solving skills. The business elective focus area aims to prepare students to apply this foundation to business problems. Overview
textAfterTable: * A business minor must be completed for accounting classes to be counted as Technical Electives. Advising Notes To earn a business minor without taking any additional courses beyond those required to complete their B.S.E. degree, students must additionally: Satisfy their upper- or lower-level Humanities/Social Science General Education Component requirement using ECON:1100, Principles of Microeconomics (Required). Satisfy their lower-level Social Science General Education Component requirement using MGMT:2000, Introduction to Law (Required). Satisfy their upper-level from the same department as one of your Lower Level Humanities/Social Science General Education Component requirement using MKTG:3000, Introduction to Marketing Strategy (Required).
